contextId.information: The word "Jews" here represents the "Jewish leaders." AT: "the Jewish leaders sent ... to him from Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the Jews sent ... to him from Jerusalem

contextId.information: Here "the Jews" is a synecdoche which represent the "Jewish leaders." AT: "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "the Jews" is a synecdoche for "the Jewish leaders." AT: "the Jewish leaders were making plans to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the Jews were seeking to kill him

contextId.information: The word "Jews" is a synecdoche for the leaders of the Jews who opposed Jesus. AT: "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The "Jews" is a synecdoche that represents the leaders of the Jews who opposed Jesus. AT: "The Jewish leaders said among themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The Jews therefore said among themselves

contextId.information: Here the phrase "the scribes and the Pharisees" is a synecdoche that represents some of the members of these two groups. AT: "Some scribes and Pharisees brought" or "Some men who taught the Jewish laws and some who were Pharisees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The scribes and the Pharisees brought

contextId.information: Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for "the Jewish leaders." AT: "The Jewish leaders said" or "The Jewish authorities said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The "Jews" is a synecdoche that represents the "Jewish leaders" who opposed Jesus. AT: "The Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Jews" is a metonym for the "Jewish leaders" who opposed Jesus. AT: "Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the "Jews" is a synecdoche for the "Jewish leaders" who opposed Jesus. AT: "The Jewish leaders said to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Jesus" is a synecdoche for Jesus and the disciples. AT: "as Jesus and his disciples passed by" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the "Jewish leaders" who opposed Jesus. AT: Now the Jewish leaders still did not believe. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Now the Jews still did not believe

contextId.information: Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "Then the Jewish leaders surrounded him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "Then the Jewish leaders started picking up stones again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Then the Jews took up stones

contextId.information: The word "Jews" is a synecdoche that represents the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "The Jewish opponents replied" or "The Jewish leaders answered him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is a synecdoche for the Roman army. AT: "the Roman army will come" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders. AT: "walk openly among the Jewish leaders who opposed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "as I said to the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: as I said to the Jews

contextId.information: Here "Jews" is a synecdoche that refers to the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "voice" is a synecdoche that refers to words Jesus says. AT: "the things I say" or "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Pilate himself did not whip Jesus. Here "Pilate" is a synecdoche for the soldiers that Pilate ordered to whip Jesus. AT: "Then Pilate ordered his soldiers to whip Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Then Pilate took Jesus and whipped him

contextId.information: Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "The Jewish leaders answered Pilate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "he" refers to Pilate and is a synecdoche for "Pilate ordered the soldiers." AT: "he ordered the soldiers to bring Jesus out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "Jews" is a synecdoche that refers to the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "Pilate said to the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "I" is a synecdoche that refers to Pilate's soldiers who will actually perform the crucifixion. AT: "Do you really want me to tell my soldiers to nail your king to a cross?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "Pilate" is a synecdoche for the person who wrote on the sign. Here "on the cross" refers to Jesus' cross. AT: "Pilate also commanded someone to write on a sign and to attach it to Jesus' cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Pilate also wrote a sign and put it on the cross

contextId.information: Here "Jews" is a synecdoche for the Jewish leaders who opposed Jesus. AT: "the Jewish leaders" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
